name: Clear repository cache by key

input_parameters.description: Request schema for the `ClearRepositoryCacheByKey` action, defining parameters to identify and delete GitHub Actions caches.

key.description: The exact cache key used to identify specific caches for deletion. This key is often dynamically generated in workflows using expressions (e.g., `${{ runner.os }}-npm-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json') }}`).
key.title: Key

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

ref.description: The full Git reference for narrowing down the cache deletion. For example, to target caches for a specific branch, use `refs/heads/<branch_name>`. To target caches for a pull request, use `refs/pull/<pull_number>/merge`. If omitted, caches matching the key across all refs are considered.
ref.title: Ref

repo.description: The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

input_parameters.title: ClearRepositoryCacheByKeyRequest

data.description: A dictionary typically containing `total_count`, the number of caches deleted, and `actions_caches`, an array of the deleted cache objects.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

description: Deletes github actions caches from a repository matching a specific `key` and an optional git `ref`, used to manage storage or clear outdated/corrupted caches; the action succeeds even if no matching caches are found to delete.

name: Compare two commits

input_parameters.description: Request schema for `CompareTwoCommits` action. Specifies the repository and the two commit points (base and head) to compare.

basehead.description: A string specifying the base and head references to compare, in the format `BASE...HEAD`. `BASE` and `HEAD` can be branch names (e.g., `main...develop`), tag names (e.g., `v1.0.0...v1.1.0`), or commit SHA-1s. Both references must exist in the specified repository. To compare branches across forks in the same network, use the format `OWNER:REF...OWNER:REF` (e.g., `octocat:main...another-user:main`).
basehead.title: Basehead

owner.description: The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

page.description: Page number of the results to fetch, for pagination when the number of differences (commits or files) is large.
page.title: Page

per_page.description: Number of results (e.g., files or commits) to return per page, with a maximum of 100, for pagination.
per_page.title: Per Page

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

input_parameters.title: CompareTwoCommitsRequest

data.description: A dictionary containing the comparison details. This typically includes: the status of the comparison (e.g., 'diverged', 'ahead', 'behind', 'identical'), the number of commits `ahead_by` and `behind_by` the base, `total_commits` in the range, an array of `commits` objects, an array of `files` objects detailing changed files (including status, additions, deletions, changes, patch, etc.), and various URLs (`html_url`, `permalink_url`, `diff_url`, `patch_url`) for accessing the comparison.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

description: Compares two commit points (commits, branches, tags, or shas) within a repository or across forks, using `base...head` or `owner:ref...owner:ref` format for the `basehead` parameter.

active.description: Boolean indicating if the webhook is active. `true` sends notifications, `false` does not. Defaults to `true`.

config__content__type.description: The media type for serializing webhook payloads. Supported: `json`, `form`. GitHub API defaults to `form` if this field is not set or is `None`.

name: Create a check run

input_parameters.description: Request schema to create a new check run on GitHub.

actions.description: A list of up to three action objects defining interactive buttons displayed on GitHub after the check run completes. Each object needs a `label` (button text), `identifier` (unique ID for the action), and `description` (tooltip). Clicking a button sends a `check_run.requested_action` webhook to your app.
actions.title: Actions

completed_at.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) indicating when the check run finished. **Required if `status` is `completed`**.
completed_at.title: Completed At

conclusion.description: **Required if `completed_at` is provided or if `status` is `completed`**. Specifies the final outcome of the check (e.g., 'success', 'failure'). Note: Setting `conclusion` automatically sets `status` to `completed`. GitHub alone can set a conclusion to `stale`.
conclusion.title: Conclusion

details_url.description: The URL of the integrator's site providing full details of the check. If omitted, the GitHub App's homepage is used. This URL is available from the check's UI.
details_url.title: Details Url

external_id.description: A unique identifier for the check run on the integrator's system. This helps in correlating check runs between GitHub and the external system.
external_id.title: External Id

head_sha.description: The SHA of the commit for which the check run is created.
head_sha.title: Head Sha

name.description: The name of the check to be displayed in the GitHub UI. For example, "Code Coverage" or "Linter".
name.title: Name

output__annotations.description: A list of annotation objects detailing issues at specific code locations. Annotations are visible in the 'Checks' and 'Files changed' tabs of a pull request. Each annotation object should specify `path`, `start_line`, `end_line`, `annotation_level` ('notice', 'warning', or 'failure'), and `message`. Optional fields include `start_column`, `end_column`, `title`, and `raw_details`. Up to 50 annotations per API request; for more, use subsequent 'Update a check run' calls. GitHub Actions limits are 10 warnings and 10 errors per step.
output__annotations.title: Output  Annotations

output__images.description: A list of image objects to display in the check run's output in the GitHub UI. Each object requires `alt` (alternative text), `image_url` (URL of the image), and an optional `caption`.
output__images.title: Output  Images

output__summary.description: A summary of the check run's findings. Supports Markdown. **Maximum length**: 65,535 characters.
output__summary.title: Output  Summary

output__text.description: Detailed textual information about the check run's output. Supports Markdown. **Maximum length**: 65,535 characters.
output__text.title: Output  Text

output__title.description: A descriptive title for the output of the check run, displayed in the GitHub UI. For example, 'Linter Scan Summary'.
output__title.title: Output  Title

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

started_at.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) indicating when the check run began.
started_at.title: Started At

status.description: The current status of the check run. Only GitHub Actions can set `status` to `waiting`, `pending`, or `requested`.
status.title: Status

input_parameters.title: CreateACheckRunRequest

data.description: A dictionary representing the full check run object as created by the API. This includes fields like `id`, `node_id`, `head_sha`, `status`, `conclusion`, `name`, `details_url`, `external_id`, `started_at`, `completed_at`, `output` (containing summary, text, annotations, images), `app` (information about the GitHub App that created the check run), and `pull_requests` (an array of pull requests associated with the commit).
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

Request body for POST /user/codespaces.

Provide either:
- repository_id (int) + ref (string branch/commit/PR ref), or
- pull_request object with pull_request_number (int) and repository_id (int).

Other optional fields supported by the API (machine, location, devcontainer_path, etc.) can be added later if needed.

successful.title: Successful

idle_timeout_minutes.title: Idle Timeout Minutes

name: Create a pull request

input_parameters.description: Request schema for `CreateAPullRequest`

name: Create a release

body.description: A detailed description of the release. Markdown formatting is supported.

- Feature A
- Feature B

Optionally, specify `line` (or `start_line` for multi-line), and `side` (or `start_side`) for diff location. `position` is deprecated; use `line`. Example: `[{'path': 'file.py', 'line': 10, 'body': 'Refactor this.'}]`

side.title: SideEnm

start_line.description: The start line number for multi-line comments

start_side.title: SideEnm

items.title: ReviewComment

comments.title: Comments

event.title: EventEnm

owner.title: Owner

pull_number.title: Pull Number

repo.title: Repo

successful.title: Successful

permissions__security__events.description: Permission for security events (e.g., code scanning alerts). Applies to target repositories.
permissions__security__events.title: Permissions  Security  Events

permissions__single__file.description: Permission to manage a single file. Requires `repository_ids` set to a single repository and `repositories` to a single file path.
permissions__single__file.title: Permissions  Single  File

permissions__starring.description: Permission to list and manage repositories a user is starring. Applies to target user.
permissions__starring.title: Permissions  Starring

permissions__statuses.description: Permission for commit statuses. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__statuses.title: Permissions  Statuses

permissions__team__discussions.description: Permission for team discussions and related comments. Applies to target organization.
permissions__team__discussions.title: Permissions  Team  Discussions

permissions__vulnerability__alerts.description: Permission for Dependabot alerts. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__vulnerability__alerts.title: Permissions  Vulnerability  Alerts

permissions__workflows.description: Permission for updating GitHub Actions workflow files. Requires `contents: write`. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__workflows.title: Permissions  Workflows

repositories.description: Repository names to scope the new token to. Cannot be used if `repository_ids` is specified.
repositories.title: Repositories

repository_ids.description: Repository IDs to scope the new token to. Cannot be used if `repositories` is specified.
repository_ids.title: Repository Ids

target.description: Username or organization name for scoping the new token. Required if `target_id` is not provided.
target.title: Target

target_id.description: ID of the user or organization for scoping the new token. Required if `target` is not provided.
target_id.title: Target Id

input_parameters.title: CreateAScopedAccessTokenRequest

data.description: Details of the newly created scoped access token, including the token, `expires_at`, `permissions`, and repository scope.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

description: Exchanges a user-to-server token for a new, fine-grained scoped access token for a github app, requiring `client id`, `access token`, either `target` or `target id`, and at least one permission; for repository-specific scoping, provide either `repositories` (names) or `repository ids` (ids), but not both.

name: Create a dependency snapshot

input_parameters.description: Input for creating a dependency snapshot, capturing the repository's dependency state at a specific commit.

detector__name.description: Optional name of the tool used to detect dependencies.
detector__name.title: Detector  Name

detector__url.description: Optional URL of the detector tool used.
detector__url.title: Detector  Url

detector__version.description: Optional version of the detector tool used.
detector__version.title: Detector  Version

job__correlator.description: Optional string to group snapshots. For a given `job.correlator` and `detector.name`, only the 'latest' snapshot is current. Useful to distinguish detection runs (e.g., concatenating GITHUB_WORKFLOW and GITHUB_JOB).
job__correlator.title: Job  Correlator

job__html__url.description: Optional URL for the job that generated this snapshot.
job__html__url.title: Job  Html  Url

job__id.description: Optional external ID of the job that generated this snapshot.
job__id.title: Job  Id

manifests.description: Optional collection of package manifests (e.g., package-lock.json, pom.xml). Keys are manifest file names; values detail dependencies.
manifests.title: Manifests

metadata.description: Optional user-defined metadata for domain-specific information. Limited to 8 keys with scalar values (e.g., string, number, boolean).
metadata.title: Metadata

owner.description: Account owner of the repository (name is not case-sensitive).
owner.title: Owner

ref.description: Git reference (fully qualified, e.g., `refs/heads/main`) of the repository branch/tag that triggered this snapshot.
ref.title: Ref

repo.description: Repository name, without `.git` extension (name is not case-sensitive).
repo.title: Repo

scanned.description: UTC timestamp (ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) when the snapshot was taken.
scanned.title: Scanned

sha.description: Commit SHA (maximum 40 characters) associated with this dependency snapshot.
sha.title: Sha

version.description: Version of the dependency snapshot submission, typically of the manifest or lock file format.
version.title: Version

input_parameters.title: CreateASnapshotOfDependenciesForARepositoryRequest

data.description: ID of the created snapshot and a confirmation message.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

description: Creates a snapshot of a repository's dependencies to populate the github dependency graph and enable security alerts; `sha` must be a 40-character commit id, `ref` a fully qualified git reference (e.g., `refs/heads/main`), and `scanned` an iso 8601 timestamp.

name: Create a tree

input_parameters.description: Request schema for `CreateATree`

base_tree.description: SHA1 of an existing Git tree object to use as a base. If provided, its entries are combined with `tree` entries, where `tree` entries overwrite those from `base_tree` with the same path. Typically the SHA1 of the latest commit's tree for new branch changes. If omitted, the new tree is built from `tree` entries; files from the parent commit's tree not in `tree` are treated as deleted.
base_tree.title: Base Tree

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

tree.description: List of objects defining the tree structure. Each object (node) requires `path` (string), `mode` (string; e.g., '100644' file, '100755' executable, '040000' subdirectory/tree, '160000' submodule, '120000' symlink), and `type` (string: 'blob', 'tree', or 'commit'). For new/updated blobs, provide `content` (UTF-8 string). For existing objects or `tree`/`commit` types, provide `sha` (string). To delete, specify `path`, `mode`, `type`, and set `sha` to `null`.
tree.title: Tree

input_parameters.title: CreateATreeRequest

data.description: A dictionary representing the created Git tree object. It includes the `sha` and `url` of the new tree, an array of `tree` items (nodes in the tree), and a `truncated` boolean flag indicating if the number of items in the tree array exceeded the maximum limit and was cut short.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

description: Creates a new git tree object in a repository, defining file/directory structure by specifying tree entries, optionally building on a `base tree` sha; all provided shas must be valid.

name: List repository activities

input_parameters.description: Request schema for `ListRepositoryActivities`

activity_type.description: Filters activities by a specific type, such as 'push' or 'pr_merge'. If unspecified, all relevant activity types are returned.
activity_type.title: Activity Type

actor.description: The GitHub username of the person who performed the activity. Filters activities to only those performed by this user.

after.description: A pagination cursor. Returns activity items that occurred after this cursor. This cursor is typically obtained from the `Link` header in a previous API response. For more details, see GitHub's REST API documentation on "Using pagination in the REST API" and "Using Link headers".
after.title: After

before.description: A pagination cursor. Returns activity items that occurred before this cursor. This cursor is typically obtained from the `Link` header in a previous API response. For more details, see GitHub's REST API documentation on "Using pagination in the REST API" and "Using Link headers".
before.title: Before

direction.description: The direction to sort the activity results. Use 'asc' for ascending (oldest first) or 'desc' for descending (newest first).

owner.description: The account owner of the repository (e.g., a GitHub username or organization name). This name is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

per_page.description: The number of activity results to return per page. Maximum value is 100. For more information, see the GitHub REST API guide on "Using pagination in the REST API".
per_page.title: Per Page

ref.description: The Git reference for which to list activities (e.g., a branch name like `main` or a full ref like `refs/heads/main`). If unspecified, activities from all branches are listed.
ref.title: Ref

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

time_period.description: Filters activities based on a predefined time period. For example, 'day' retrieves activities from the last 24 hours, and 'week' from the last 7 days (168 hours).

branch.title: Branch

created.description: Filter by creation date or date-time range (ISO8601 format: YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). Supports operators like `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`, and `..` for ranges.

event.title: Event

name: Create a pull request

input_parameters.description: Request schema for `CreateAPullRequest`

issue.description: The number of an existing issue in the repository to convert into a pull request. If provided, the issue's title and body may be used for the pull request. Required if `title` is not specified.
issue.title: Issue

maintainer_can_modify.description: Indicates whether maintainers of the upstream repository can modify the pull request. This is primarily relevant for pull requests originating from forks.
maintainer_can_modify.title: Maintainer Can Modify

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.

name: Create a review for a pull request

Optionally, specify `line` (or `start_line` for multi-line), and `side` (or `start_side`) for diff location. `position` is deprecated; use `line`. Example: `[{'path': 'file.py', 'line': 10, 'body': 'Refactor this.'}]`

items.description: Schema for individual review comments

body.description: The text of the comment
body.title: Body

line.description: The line number in the diff to comment on (required for single-line comments)
line.title: Line

path.title: Path

side.description: The side of the diff to place the comment on (LEFT or RIGHT)
side.title: SideEnm

start_line.description: The start line number for multi-line comments
start_line.title: Start Line

start_side.description: The side of the diff to start a multi-line comment on
start_side.title: SideEnm

items.title: ReviewComment

comments.title: Comments

commit_id.description: SHA of the commit to review; defaults to the latest pull request commit. Outdated SHAs may lead to stale comments.
commit_id.title: Commit Id

event.description: Review action type (`APPROVE`, `REQUEST_CHANGES`, `COMMENT`); if omitted, review is `PENDING` and requires later submission.
event.title: EventEnm

owner.description: Username of the account owning the repository (case-insensitive).
owner.title: Owner

pull_number.description: Identifying number of the pull request.
pull_number.title: Pull Number

repo.description: Repository name, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
repo.title: Repo

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not

body.description: Text content of the review comment.
body.title: Body

commit_id.description: SHA of the commit for the comment. Using an outdated `commit_id` can misplace the comment if lines change.
commit_id.title: Commit Id

in_reply_to.description: ID of an existing review comment to reply to. If provided, other location parameters (except `body`) are ignored.
in_reply_to.title: In Reply To

line.description: **Required unless `subject_type` is 'file'**. Line number in the diff for the comment; for multi-line, this is the last line of the range.

owner.title: Owner

If `path` points to a file, this dictionary includes keys such as `name`, `path`, `sha`, `size`, `type` ('file'), `content` (Base64 encoded string of the file's contents), and `download_url`. If `path` points to a directory, this dictionary represents metadata for the directory object itself (e.g., its `name`, `path`, `sha`, `type` ('dir')). Note: To list the actual items *within* a directory, a different API endpoint or action might be needed, as the GitHub API returns an array of items for directory listings.

order.description: Determines the sorting order of results, either 'asc' (ascending) or 'desc' (descending). This parameter is only effective when `sort` is also specified. Defaults to 'desc'.

page.description: The page number of the results to retrieve, starting from 1. For more information, see "[Using pagination in the REST API](https://docs.github.com/rest/using-the-rest-api/using-pagination-in-the-rest-api)."

data.description: A dictionary representing the search results. This typically includes keys such as `total_count` (the total number of labels found), `incomplete_results` (a boolean indicating if the search timed out), and `items` (a list of label objects matching the query). Each label object in the `items` list contains details like `id`, `node_id`, `url`, `name`, `description`, `color` (hexadecimal code without '#'), and `default` (boolean indicating if it's a default label).

For more information, see "[Managing categories for discussions in your repository](https://docs.github.com/discussions/managing-discussions-for-your-community/managing-categories-for-discussions-in-your-repository)."

Defaults to `true` for newly published releases. `legacy` specifies that the latest release should be determined based on the release creation date and higher semantic version.

tag_name.description: The name of the tag. This can be an existing tag or a new tag name.

The notification setting the team has chosen. Editing teams without specifying this parameter leaves `notification_setting` intact.
  - `notifications_enabled`: Team members receive notifications when the team is @mentioned.
  - `notifications_disabled`: No one receives notifications for team @mentions.

To remove an existing parent team relationship and make this a top-level team, explicitly pass `null` for this field (e.g., by setting this parameter to Python `None`). If this parameter is not provided in the request, the current parent team, if any, remains unchanged.
parent_team_id.title: Parent Team Id

privacy.description:
The desired privacy level for the team. Editing teams without specifying this parameter leaves `privacy` intact. When a team is nested, the `privacy` for parent teams cannot be `secret`.
  - For a non-nested team:
    - `secret`: Visible only to organization owners and members of this team.
    - `closed`: Visible to all members of this organization.
  - For a parent or child team:
    - `closed`: Visible to all members of this organization.
privacy.title: Privacy

'master' uses the master (or main) branch. 'master /docs' uses the /docs folder on the master (or main) branch. This parameter is ignored if `build_type` is 'workflow'.

If this field is omitted in the request, the repository's existing `auto_trigger_checks` preferences are not modified by this specific update action.

company.description: The new company affiliation for the user. Provide `null` to clear the existing company. For example, 'GitHub'.

name: Upload an analysis as sarif data

input_parameters.description: Request schema for `UploadAnAnalysisAsSarifData`

checkout_uri.description: The base URI of the checkout directory as it appears in the SARIF file. This property is used to convert absolute file paths to relative paths, enabling alerts to be correctly mapped to their location in the repository.
checkout_uri.title: Checkout Uri

commit_sha.description: The SHA of the commit to which the analysis you are uploading relates. Must be a 40-character Git SHA.
commit_sha.title: Commit Sha

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This is case-insensitive.
owner.title: Owner

ref.description: The full Git reference for the analysis, formatted as `refs/heads/<branch name>`, `refs/tags/<tag>`, `refs/pull/<number>/merge`, or `refs/pull/<number>/head`.
ref.title: Ref

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is case-insensitive.
repo.title: Repo

sarif.description: A Base64 encoded string of a gzipped SARIF file. For more information, see '[SARIF support for code scanning](https://docs.github.com/code-security/secure-coding/sarif-support-for-code-scanning)'.
examples: eJzVst... (actual gzipped and Base64 encoded SARIF content)
sarif.title: Sarif

started_at.description: The timestamp indicating when the analysis run began, in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.
started_at.title: Started At

tool_name.description: Name of the tool that generated the analysis. GitHub defaults this to "API" if omitted. A tool GUID in the SARIF can be used for filtering alerts.
tool_name.title: Tool Name

validate.description: Specifies whether the uploaded SARIF file should be validated against the code scanning specifications. This is useful for integrators to ensure their SARIF files are correctly processed and rendered by GitHub.
validate.title: Validate

input_parameters.title: UploadAnAnalysisAsSarifDataRequest

error.title: Error

successful.title: Successful

description: Tool to generate an embeddable google map url and html iframe code. use when you need to display a map (place, view, directions, street view, search) on a webpage without javascript.

name: Nearby search

excludedTypes.description: Place types to exclude (e.g., 'cafe', 'store'); results matching any of these types are omitted. For supported types, see Google Maps Places API documentation.
excludedTypes.title: Excluded Types

fieldMask.description: Comma-separated list of place fields for the response (e.g., 'places.displayName,places.formattedAddress'); use '*' for all fields.
fieldMask.title: Field Mask

includedTypes.description: Place types to include (e.g., 'restaurant', 'park'); results will match at least one of these types. For supported types, see Google Maps Places API documentation.
includedTypes.title: Included Types

latitude.description: Latitude coordinate of the search center in decimal degrees.
latitude.title: Latitude

longitude.description: Longitude coordinate of the search center in decimal degrees.
longitude.title: Longitude

maxResultCount.description: Maximum number of search results to return (up to 20); the actual count may be lower.
maxResultCount.title: Max Result Count

radius.description: Radius of the circular search area in meters.
radius.title: Radius

data.description: Data from the action execution

places.description: List of found places matching search criteria; each place is a dictionary of requested fields.
places.title: Places

data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

description: Searches for places (e.g., restaurants, parks) within a specified circular area, with options to filter by place types and customize the returned fields and number of results.

name: Text Search

fieldMask.description: Comma-separated list of place fields to return. Use `*` for all fields (not recommended for performance/cost). See Google Maps Places API documentation for field names.
fieldMask.title: Field Mask

maxResultCount.description: Maximum number of place results to return (must be 1-20). Note: Google prefers `pageSize`, but this action uses `maxResultCount`.
maxResultCount.title: Max Result Count

textQuery.description: Text query for searching places. Matched against place name, address, and category.
textQuery.title: Text Query

data.description: Data from the action execution

places.description: List of places matching the query. Fields for each place are determined by the request's `fieldMask`.
places.title: Places

data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

description: Searches for places on google maps using a textual query (e.g., "restaurants in london", "eiffel tower").
